result.execSummary:
The defendant Terrence L Patterson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Battery, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

SLH: this is acceptable - need not report to jail
of Right to Seek Postconviction Relief filed

2:50 PM - Def in court w/Atty Daniel Mark Norland.  Noel Ann Lawrence appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Amended Information filed
Ct. 1 - battery - NO CONTEST
  Plea Quest filed/signed/understands
  Statement as to Neg. Plea filed
Understands const rights waived
Understands elements of crime
No promises/threats
No alc/drugs/meds in the last 24 hrs  
Plea is F, V & I made. Sufficient factual basis to support the plea and the def is found guilty.
LAWRENCE: he's doing well in the CHIPS case but the extra supervision would be approp. NORLAND: he's a single dad - mom hasn't been in the picture for most of their lives. He's attending counseling and things are going well. I don't know probation could accomplish anything more than the current case. CRT: COMPAS suggests low risk . LAWRENCE: probation is recommended by the state due to the seriousness of the offense. It's just increased supervision thru the DOC. CRT: I won't order probation but given the risk level and the needs are being met I will give you a chance to do com service
SENTENCE: 10 days CJ - def can do 80 hrs com service in lieu of jail time. Report to jail by 11/20 by 6 pm. 
pay CC  - def to pay $25/mo eff 11/1 or CJ
ejss

Def in court w/Atty Daniel Mark Norland.  Noel Ann Lawrence appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Norland: CPS records would be helpful in assisting a resolution but they become public record so I have an auth from the def allowing me to turn over specific records to DA's office and then the records be sealed in the DA's file. CRT: if there are confidential records, they are kept in a confidential envelope and are statutorily due confidentiality. There's no record that they be disclosed publicly. You can disclose them to State and go from there.
